body.value: Tabrobanen habet x civitates, bis in anno merita fruges.
Taprobane has ten cities, [and] twice a year reaps crops/fruits.

Modern-day Sri Lanka. Orosius (1.2.15): quae habet decem civitates [which has ten cities]; and Isidore (14.6.12): in uno anno duas esse aestates et duas hiemes, et bis floribus vernare locum [in one year, there are two summers and two winters, and in the spring it is a place of two flowerings].
Isidore (14.3.7) describes the gold mountains (montes aurei) in India, guarded by dragons, griffons and immense, monstrous giants. Associated with the icon of a mountain.
India, in qua sunt gentes xliiii.
Mentioned in Orosius (1.2.17) alongside four other regions between the Indus and Tigris Rivers. See notes in Aracusia.
Mentioned in Orosius (1.2.17) alongside four other regions between the Indus and Tigris Rivers: Parthia, Assyria, Persida, and Media.

The Phison River is one of the four rivers that Genesis 2:11 names as tributaries of the river flowing out of the Garden of Eden. It also notes that the Phison encircles the land of Hevilath, or Evilath in the Cotton Map, located just above the river's inscription.
The Phison River, which encircled the land of Havilah, is supposed to have been the first river to flow out of the Garden of Eden.

There is a graceful and detailed figure of a lion included below the inscription, the only depiction of an animal on the map. 

The source for this inscription remains uncertain. Beazley (611) notes that "there are several names and several features [on the Cotton Map] which show striking independence of any other known map-authority in the early Middle Ages. Among these are...abundant lions of the northeast of Asia." 

Two possible origins arise. First, Isidore of Seville mentions lions in Albania (14.3.34): Albania a colore populi nuncupata, eo quod alba crine nascantur. Haec ab orient sub mare Caspium surgens, per ora Oceani spetentionalis usque ad Maeotides paludes per deserta et inculta extenditur. Huic terrae canes ingentes sunt, tantaeque feritatis ut tauros premant, leones perimant. [In this land there are giant dogs, so fierce that they overwhelm bulls and kill lions.] While Albania is usually located more towards the west, the Saint Sever Beatus Map (Miller, vol.1, 48) shows Albania to be in the same location as the Cotton Map. 

Second, Harley and Woodward (336) note a possible evangelical connection since the lion is the symbol for Mark, and is associated with the cardinal direction east.

Related to boreas, north. Perhaps a corruption of Orosius (1.2.47): ad promunturium Boreum et flumen Boreum [up until the promontory of the North and the river of the North]. The promontory of Boreus is possibly the mountain below, to the west of the inscription. The Boreus river is possibly the one named only as “flumen” that flows from this mountain, or possibly the unnamed river more directly below it, flowing southwest from the ocean, next to the inscription Gentes xliii .
This area is known to contain only forty-two peoples (Orosius 1.2.47), thus there may have been a transcription error.
This is possibly the Boreus River. Orosius (1.2.47): usque ad promunturium Boreum et flumen Boreum [up until the promontory of Boreum and the river of Boreum.]
Perhaps because of the length of this range, the Cotton Map contains two incidences of these mountains, this one and one to the west Mons Taurus.

Given this location's relative proximity to Arachosia, Media and Persia, it is likely that this is Assyria, rather than Syria. Mentioned in Orosius (1.2.17) alongside four other regions between the Indus and Tigris Rivers. See notes in Aracusia.

The figure of the mountain to the left of the inscription may refer to the Caucasian Mountains; or this could be the Zagros mountain range, found today in northern Iraq.
The medial "n" of the inscription is obscured by another mark, possibly a different character with an ascender, suggesting the scribe perhaps mistranscribed the inscription on the first try.
Mentioned in Orosius (1.2.17) alongside four other regions between the Indus and Tigris Rivers. See "Notes" in Aracusia.
Orosius (1.2.21): cui ad meridiem succedit Babylonia, deinde Chaldaea, nouissime Arabia Eudaemon [which follows to the south Babylonia, then Chaldea, the most recent Arabia Eudemon].
Hic dicitur esse mons Sup(er) Ardens.
Here there is said to be a mountain burning at the top.

The Nile river is represented in two separate sections. The first is seen here, in red, transecting the inscription. The second section, also in red, is unnamed, beginning further to the northwest (below and to the left) and running west.
One of the twelve tribes of Israel.
Accompanied with a large, six-towered walled city, with front entrance.
Ancient Armenian kingdom of the Hellenistic period.
Mount Phasga is mentioned in Deuteronomy 34:1. Analogues in Hereford and Ebstorf Maps.
Zugis regio ipsa e(st) et affrica; e(st) enim fortis, sed uberior bestiis et serpentibus plena, amnis Misica
This region is Zeugis and Africa; [it] is indeed powerful, but also more abundant with beasts and full of serpents; river Misica [corruption of flumine Amisiga?]

In part a conflation and/or corruption of Isidore (14.5.8-9): Zeugis, ubi Carthago magna. Ipsa est et vera Africa inter Byzacium et Numidiam sita, a septentrione mari Siculo iuncta, et a meridie usque ad Gaetulorum regionem porrecta; cuius proxima quaeque frugifera sunt, ulteriora autem bestiis et serpentibus plena, atque onagris magnisin deserto vagantibus. Gaetulia autem Africae pars mediterranea est. Numidia ab incolis passim vagantibus sic vocata, quod nullam certam haberent sedem. Nam lingua eorum incertae sedes et vagae 'numidia' dicuntur. Incipit autem a flumine Amsiga, in Zeugitanum limitem definit... [Greater Carthage is in Zeugis. This is the true Africa, situated in between Byzacium and Numidia, bounded in the north by the Sicilian Sea. In the south it stretches as far as the region of the Gaetuli. The nearer part of it is fruitful, but the more remote part is filled with wild beasts and serpents and great onagers wandering in the desert. Gaetulia is the interior region of Africa. Numidia is so called after inhabitants that wander about far and wide because they do not have a fixed abode. For in their language temporary and mobile settlements are called Numidia. It begins at the river Amsiga and it marks its end in Zeugis . . .]; translation by Barney, Lewis, Beach, and Berghof.
The peoples of Gaulolum, extending all the way to the ocean
Inscription reads -aulolum; the initial G is missing.

There are very few mythical beasts present on this map, but the Cinocephali are a popular feature on medieval mappaemundi. They are here located in a similar space as on the Psalter map. The related Hereford and Sawley maps give the dog-headed people a Northern home.
Note the presence of Sclaui (Slavs) just above the presence of Sleswic (Slavs).

This inscription uses the Old English letter ƿ (wynn). Schleswig is a region on the Danish peninsula with strong Viking and Saxon connections. Note the presence of Sclaui (Slavs) just above the presence of Sleswic (Schleswig / Slavs).

On a large peninsula jutting out into the North Sea, the inscription itself is unusual, but almost certainly refers to Norway. Miller (vol. 3, 32) suggests that the mapmaker crossed out an "erroneous" beginning - "Nero," leaving the remaining letters to be read as Norweci.
Scribal error/anomaly of Daria for Dacia
The inscription is jumbled, with the final two letters "da" belonging at the beginning rather than the end. This inscription also belongs to the river drawn below it (to the West).
An ethnonym, with toponymic leanings. The Bulgars were a semi-nomadic ethnic group of Turkic origin, migrating from Central Asia to Eastern Europe in the fifth century and later.
Displaced from its actual geographic location.
Scride-Finns, Sliding/Snowshoeing/Skiing Finns; the Sami People

Mentioned in the Old English Orosius (1.1.47), as well as the Old English poem Widsith. Also known as Screrefennae (and one of the subgroups of Ptolomy's Phinnoi), in Jordanes' sixth-century De origine actibusque Getarum (The Origin and Deeds of the Getae/Goths) (3.21). See Bosworth-Toller's entry for Scride-finnas and Finnas for etymology and other occurrences in Old English.
The location of this inscription cannot refer to the Messina in Italy. It may therefore refer to the region of Moesia, north of Thrace, or Messembria, a city north of Constantinople on the Black Sea.
Constantinople is usually labelled Constantinopolis, thus it is feasible that the inscription reads: constantinopoli m(etropolis).

Associated with an image of a mountain range. The Riphean Mountains were considered a natural boundary between Europe and Asia, and although there has been no definitive identification of this legendary mountain range, they are at times thought to refer to the Ural Mountains which run roughly north to south through western Russia and into Kazakhstan.
Griphes (or Griffons) are also mentioned in the Hereford Map, but as animals, not people.
An ethnonym relating to to the ancient Turkic peoples hailing from Central Asia and Siberia who settled across Eastern Europe and Asia Minor.

No identifying inscription is included for this mountain. However the inscription occurs close to the Caspian Sea, and thick vertical lines to the right and left create boundaries that include this mountain, the region of the Albani, and the province of the Colchi. The Albani and Colchi peoples are purported to have inhabited the Caucasian mountains (Orosius, 1.2.36-40). Alternatively, the Hereford map has an inscription of the Achen/Acheron River in approximately the same location, stating that the river cascades from the Umbrosi mountains (ab umerosis montibus).
Orosius (1.2.23): a civitate Dagusa [at/by the city of Dascusa]. This inscription is accompanied with a small icon to the southeast, but it is unclear as to what exactly it represents.
Perhaps because of the length of this range, the Cotton Map contains two incidences of these mountains, this one and one to the east.
This inscription features a long-tailed "r" in the middle of the word. This letterform is also found in the inscription for Suðbrẏttas.
Cilicia is a name for the southern coastal area of Asia Minor.
The placement here of Mount Olympus is far from its actual location, being on the wrong side of the Aegean Sea.
One of the twelve tribes of Israel. One of two occurrences. Second Neptalim occurs away from this general grouping of tribes of Israel, to the south and slightly to the west, just above Alexandria.
One of the twelve tribes of Israel. One of two occurrences. Zabulon 2 also occurs in the general grouping of the Israelite tribes, just two inscriptions over to the south.

One of the twelve tribes of Israel.

Previous readings: Miller (vol. 3, 34) - Manase; McGurk (86) - Masiase for Manases. The ascender of the first "s" (as transcribed by McGurk) is interpreted here as a slipped penstroke meant to indicate an abbreviation above an "n", making it a double nasal consonant in line with the name of the tribe Man(n)asse. An abbreviated "n", or corruption thereof, is noted here rather than the insertion of an "si", given that another inscription, the half-tribe of Manasseh, is written just above this inscription with one "n", and no "si".
One of the twelve tribes of Israel.
One of the twelve tribes of Israel.
One of the twelve tribes of Israel. One of two occurrences. Other Zabulon also occurs in the general grouping of the Israelite tribes, just two inscriptions to the north.
One of the twelve tribes of Israel.
One of the twelve tribes of Israel. See also the inscription for the tribe of Manasse located northwest of this one.
One of the twelve tribes of Israel.
One of the tribes of Israel.
One of the twelve tribes of Israel.
One of two occurrences. Other Libia Ethiopium is further to the west, at the bottom of one of the strands of the Nile River.

One of two occurrences. Other Aniclea occurs to the south and west, due south of Alexandria. The Tournai Map of Asia (BL Add MS 10049 f. 64r) shows Eracleos in the same location. The first three letters, Era-, have been corrupted into Ani-, an easy slip since the same number and type of minims are demanded in both occurrences. The Ebstorf map has an analogue in the same location: Heracleon. It is likely meant to represent the ancient city of Thonis-Heracleion, once situated on the Canopic mouth of the Nile, but now sunken deep under water.

Less likely might be a possible corruption of Amalechites, as the Amalakites were described in the Bible as a nomadic tribe. 

Previous readings include Miller's version (vol. 3, 34) of Amyclee, an alternate name for the ancient Egyptian city of Canope.
One of two occurrences. Other Pentapolis occurs much farther west and slightly to the south, below Alexandria.
Accompanied with an icon that may denote a half open canopied shrine.
Gaetuli was the Romanised name of an ancient Berber tribe inhabiting Getulia.
It is unclear which of the nearby mountains is meant to represent Mount Atlas.
Text extremely unclear, but most likely some form of the city of Armagh. Associated with an architectural icon denoting a building or city walls.

The inscription may have another letter after the "n" of Tylen, but what that letter may be, remains unclear. The island of Thule, labeled here as Tylen - a place known to classical antiquity as an extreme northern land where the sun never sets in summer, and never rises in winter - has been identified variously as Scandinavia, Norway, Shetland, Orkney, Greenland, Iceland, and other regions of the Arctic circle.
The "g" in this inscription appears to be an Anglo-Saxon square minuscule "g" - unlike the Anglo-Carolingian "g" usually used on the map.

The inscription is compressed at the end; it is possible that a "t" is conflated with the "u," and that the final stroke represents a long "s."

Orosius (1.2.104): Barcilonam. Classical Latin name: Barcino, declined Barcinone, Barcinonem, Barcinonam, Barcinona.

Previous readings: Miller (vol. 3, 31) - Barcinuna civ(itas); McGurk (86) - Bartimina civ(itas).
This inscription utilizes both the long-tailed "r" and the Old English letterform ð ("eth"), one of only four instances of non-Latin characters on the map.
River flows up through the inscription and into the Black Sea.

It appears that the last "-na" of Rauen-na is accidentally repeated, on the left and right sides of the large architectural icon that divides the label into syllables. The inscription is accompanied with a three-turreted enclosure denoting the city walls.

Likely denotes the pre-English, native name for the northwestern region of the Cumbric speaking peoples (Cumbria or Cambria), originally covering what is now lowland Scotland and northern England. The term is also related to Cymri (also Cambria), the name for what becomes Wales, at times represented as geographically distinct from this southern region.

Glamorgan, a province in the south of medieval Wales.

Previous variants: Miller (vol. 3, 32) - Marinus portus (Morenpergas); McGurk (87) - Morini portus; Shannon (31-2 and plate 15) - Murus Pictis.

Though it is illogical, due to its geographic inaccuracy, Cantia (Kent), following Miller (vol. 3, 32) and McGurk (86), remains the most attested reading here. Using geographical location to dictate other possibilities, potential readings include Saervrig (Salisbury), a corruption of the Old English Searoburg - Searobvrig in the dative and genitive. Here the first three letters would be Sae- Alternatively the first two letters may be Ex-, in which case Exonia (Exeter) becomes an option. Finally the first three letters may be San-, the beginning of a place name with Santis, but followed with no specific Saint's name.
This inscription is written across three lines, to the east of a small architectural icon. The initial letter "ƿ" (wynn) also features in the inscription Morenƿergas in Britain.

Both Orosius (1.2.78) and Isidore (14.6.5) note that the Orkneys consist of thirty-three islands, thirteen of which are inhabited. The Cotton Map assigns the thirteen letters of the inscription o-r-c-a-d-e-s i-n-s-u-l-a (eschewing the more accurate plural form insulae) to individual islands, and then includes ten more un-lettered islands to represent the islands that remain uninhabited.
Orosius (1.2.8) notes that along with Egypt, Alexandria marks the beginning of Africa.
One of the twelve tribes of Israel. One of two occurrences. Other Neptalim occurs in a general grouping of tribes of Israel, to the north and slightly to the east.

One of two occurrences. The other Aniclea is located to the north and east of this inscription, due east of Hebron. The Tournai Map of Asia (BL Add MS 10049 f. 64r) shows Eracleos in the same location. The first three letters, Era-, have been corrupted into Ani-, an easy slip since the same number and type of minims are demanded in both occurrences.The Ebstorf map has an analogue in the same location: Heracleon. It is likely meant to represent the ancient city of Thonis-Heracleion, once situated on the Canopic mouth of the Nile, but now sunken deep under water. 

Less likely might be a possible corruption of Amalechites, as the Amalakites were described in the Bible as a nomadic tribe.

Previous readings include Miller's version (vol. 3, 34) of Amyclee, an alternate name for the ancient Egyptian city of Canope.
Modern-day equivalent uncertain. Orosius (1.1.8): super lacum Chalearzum [on/above Lake Calearsem]. Accompanied with an icon denoting a red lake.
One of two occurrences. Other Libia ethiopum is further to the east, to the south of the southern branch of the Nile.
The inscription should properly read Egiptus Inferior, for Lower Egypt, as this is a common toponym. However, as written, the inscription still makes sense.

One of two occurrences, linked to a figure of a four-turreted city. Other Cartago Magna appears to the southeast, along the same coastline, across the inlet from this inscription. Other Cartago Magna may depict the region rather than a city.

One of two occurrences very close to each other. This inscription appears to denote a region rather than the city. Other Cartago Magna occurs with the figure of a city, just to the northwest of this inscription, along the same coast, but across the inlet.

Orisius (1.2.90) mentions a lake that is located to the west of Tripoli and to the east of Byzacene and Numidia. This is most likely the Chott el Djerid, today an endorheic salt lake in southern Tunisia.
One of two occurrences. Other Pentapolis occurs much further east and slightly to the north, above Bethlehem.
Here in the sand [the Nile] is submerged.
One of medieval theories attributed to the River Nile is that it went underground for a while, then re-emerged on the surface, as illustrated here.
The final letter of Fons is obscured by the outline of the Nile.

Modern-day Moulouya River in Morocco.

It is unclear which of the nearby rivers (if any) accompanies this inscription.

Modern-day Tangier.

This inscription wraps around the upper side of a large, three-turreted architectural device with a very visible gateway, just to the southwest of Carthage.
